posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
For those that plan to use phoenix pro features next year:

Which Phoenix Pro License are you most likely to use for 2025 Single Device Season Pass CANivore Bus 0 voters

Which Phoenix Pro License are you most likely to use for 2025 Single Device Season Pass CANivore Bus

Which Phoenix Pro License are you most likely to use for 2025

Single Device

Season Pass

CANivore Bus

0 voters

0 voters

0 voters

I’m also curious on thoughts of buying the CANivore Bus license vs the Season Pass for teams that have multiple CANivores. It’s cheaper, and if you plan on having all CTRE devices on the CANivore, it’s easier than having to license everything (which isn’t that tedious anyway).

Here’s what I’ve been able to think of so far in terms of pros/cons of the bus license compared to the season pass. Are there any reasons to definitely choose one over the other?

Pros of CANivore Bus License

Cheaper

Less hassle for new devices

Can borrow CTRE device from another team at comp without online activation

Cons of CANivore Bus License

Only supports 2 CANivores / license

Can’t use pro on prototypes without CANivore. How useful are pro features on prototypes anyway?

polls.name: poll2
polls.title: Which Phoenix Pro License are you most likely to use for 2025

posts.name: Nick Matthes
posts.cooked:
ArchdukeTim:

Can’t use pro on prototypes without CANivore. How useful are pro features on prototypes anyway?

I am not sure that’s its pro features- but being able to run a prototype with motors and only needing a computer and a CANivore this year was awesome for us for quickly testing a prototype shooter with krakens.

Edit: I am not entirely sure if you can do this without PRO so my point may be irrelevant. The CTRE stuff has just been great for us all around.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked: You can do this with a servo tester. Krakens and Falcons still support PWM .

posts.name: Roman A.
posts.cooked: Season pass 100%, my only gripe is that 60 devices is wayyy too little lmao. Unrelated to the pass itself tho, why must we log into our ctre account evey time we open phoenix tuner to license a device… feels like you shous stsy logged in on a given device (at least for a month or two) and it just live updates your available licenses on program startup.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. Lead

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
ArchdukeTim:

it’s easier than having to license everything

I haven’t really tested this so I’m not sure, but doesn’t it make sense that if you have the season pass you could just license a CANivore?

posts.name: Nick Matthes
posts.cooked: Makes sense. Not a software guy- just noticed this was pretty useful this year. Especially when plotting various current draws and stuff through tuner when using the respective prototypes.

posts.name: Dalton
posts.cooked: We actually just pushed 2024.7.4.0 that persists your login for awhile

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
Maybe it would be nice to be able to license a CANivore with a season pass (especially if CTRE will give you more seats if you ask), but it’s clearly documented that the season pass does not work the same way, so I had no expectation of this.

I didn’t mind licensing the individual motors. It took maybe an hour to hook them all up, update them to latest firmware, and activate the license

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
We had this setup during prototyping at one point, and it was nice. We mostly used the REV hardware client since we have more spark maxes than CANivores. Same principle, and just as nice.

We might do NEOs next year for prototypes just because hardware client is simpler to set up, and supports multiple motors more easily.

For anyone complaining about being “limited” to 60 licenses - CTR very clearly states this is the initial limit. We emailed and had additional seats the same day added for us. It was painless.

Prep spares ahead of time. It really is straight forward and easy.

Team 177 | Bobcat Robotics | 2024 Build Blog Open Alliance

We’ll be using season passes again, especially with the sale going on.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Also it looks like for 2025 the limit is 100 by default

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
Waaah $150/unlimited licenses breaks my price/value comparison… /s

I’m sure the difference between 60 licenses and 100 licenses “sticker price” only matters for a few teams, but this is the first I’ve heard that the 60 wasn’t a hard limit.

posts.name: josh
posts.cooked: CANivore USB direct to Tuner X is allowed without PRO

posts.name: Vaughn Khouri
posts.cooked:
CANivore pass is probably what we’ll end up going with - we had a great experience with keeping all our devices off the Rio bus this year.

That being said, I’m going to take this opportunity to say that CTRE really needs to make it more clear when devices aren’t licensed on a CAN bus with other licensed devices activated via season pass.

This year we ran an entire competition with one of our drive motors running non-foc due to forgetting to activate it after a motor swap a few days before. It caused our entire robot to heading drift because the control curve was different, and this was especially bad on open loop control. We couldn’t figure out the root cause until after the competition. I’ve heard of this happening to other teams too…

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked:
The season pass worked great for us as we segmented our robot with a carnivore bus for the drivetrain and the regular rio bus for the upper structure. We may move to 2 canivore buses this year as we move away from rev products.

One idea to make the licensing easier is if a season pass is activated on a tuner X, let that computer continue to license devices when disconnected from internet, with the same team number. This would also allow for easier licensing at events, as internet isn’t required. It can report to CTRE the number of devices, the next time it connects. Since there isn’t a hard limit for season passes, it shouldn’t matter if it goes above 60/100

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
I think this would require CTRE removing the seat limit altogether. Which, if the season pass is only for FRC , and they’re willing to add more seats on request, why have a limit in the first place?

Could be to prevent teams from putting their license on motors not meant for FRC use, or re-selling the pro features. Though I don’t think either of these would be a widespread issue

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked:
ArchdukeTim:

or re-selling the pro features.

Even then, how does that make any sense? The season pass is tied to a specific team number and you have to have the right team number assigned to the RIO to play a match. Is it a limitation of the API that the motor itself doesn’t know the team number it was activated for? I assumed if you put 548’s season-pass-pro licensed motor in 503’s robot, it would say this license is tied to another team. Maybe it doesn’t? Perhaps a limitation to be addressed in the future?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: Oh that’s right. So yeah, I’m not totally sure what the point of the seat limit is…
